ve.usb.testMain

Class TestProgram

  • java.lang.Object
    • ve.usb.testMain.TestProgram

  • public final class TestProgram
extends java.lang.Object
    Gives a general structure for making main test programs. Test programs should provide a prompt (by convention, a tilde and a colon “~:”) wherein the user should be allowed to type any function of that class where the parameters can be passed as Strings. Generic classes should be instanced to use strings to allow this.

    So that this class knows how to call the functions of the class it is testing, it must be constructed with a Map of Callables (mapping the function's name to its respective Callable), to which it should only have to pass each of the parameters input by the user. It is the responsibility of the Callables to convert the Strings into ints (or any other appropriate type) when necessary before performing the function call, and to implement function overload (i.e. two functions with the same name, even if the number of parameters differs, will be accessed by this class via the same Callable). This class will always trim the Strings before passing them onto the Callable.

    Calling classes are hereby required include in the map the methods “help()” –which must list the methods in the Map– and “quit()” –which must cause the program to exit. By convention, the list returned by help() should be in alphabetical order.

    A sample class A, that has only one method, and uses this class to create it's test program, follows:

    class A{
        private int value;
       
        public A(){
            this.value = 0;
        }
       
        public static void main(String[] args){
            System.out.println(
                "* * * * * * * * * * * * * *\n" +
                "* 'A' class test program  *\n" +
                "* * * * * * * * * * * * * *\n" +
                "This program lets you test the A class by creating an\n" +
                "instance of A and allowing you to perform any of the\n" +
                "operations of the class on it.");
           
            A a = new A();
           
            Map<String, Callable> m = TestProgram.baseMap();
            SortedSet<String> help  = TestProgram.baseHelp();
           
            String[] subtractArgs = new String[1];
            subtractArgs[0] = "<int>";
            TestProgram.put(m, help, "subtract", new subtractCall(a), subtractArgs);
           
            TestProgram.put(m, help, "help", new TestProgram.defaultHelp(help), new String[0]);
           
            TestProgram p = new TestProgram(m);
           
            BufferedReader stdIn = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(System.in));
            while(true){
                try{
                    System.out.print("~:");
                    System.out.println( p.parseInput( stdIn.readLine() ) );
                }catch(Exception e){
                    e.printStackTrace();
                    System.err.flush();
                }
            }
        }
       
        public int subtract(int amount){
            this.value -= amount;
            return value;
        }
       
        private static class subtractCall implements Callable{
            A a;
            subtractCall(A a){
                this.a = a;
            }
           
            public String call(String[] args){
            return a.subtract( Integer.parseInt(args[0]) );
            }
            public int argNum(){
                return 1;
            }
        }
    }
    Since:
    2012-02-13
    Author:
    Fernando J. Torre

    • Method Detail

      • baseMap

        public static java.util.Map<java.lang.String,Callable> baseMap()
        Creates a map of Callables with the call to "quit()" already implemented

      • parseInput

        public java.lang.String parseInput(java.lang.String input)
                            throws java.lang.Exception
        Processes the user's input trying to identify which of the functions in the map the user has typed in, and passing the arguments to the appropriate callable
        Parameters:
        input - a string typed by the user
        Returns:
        whatever the function called returns. It is the responsibility of the caller to show this to the user through the appropriate output mechanism.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if the user wrote something that is not a function in the map, is a function called with the wrong number of parameters, or the called function generated an IllegalArgumentException
        java.lang.Exception - if the called functions generate any other kind of exception

      • stdErr

        public static java.lang.IllegalArgumentException stdErr(java.lang.String function,
                                                        java.lang.String expected,
                                                        int found)
        Prints an error message explaining that the number of arguments received was not the number expected. This function is made public to allow the Callables that prefer to handle for themselves report errors in the number of arguments in a uniform way.
        Parameters:
        function - The name of the function to be reported in the error message
        expected - The number of arguments the function expected to received
        found -
        Returns:
        an IllegalArgumentException exception with the message The function <function>must receive <expected>arguments. <found>were found

      • divideIntoArgs

        protected static java.lang.String[] divideIntoArgs(java.lang.String s)
        splits a comma-separated list into its individual components. Each component's whitespace is java.lang.String.trimmed

      • baseHelp

        public static java.util.SortedSet<java.lang.String> baseHelp()
        Creates a SortedSet containing only “quit()”. This method is created to mirror the functionality of baseMap() for TestProgram.defaultHelp

      • put

        public static void put(java.util.Map<java.lang.String,Callable> map,
                       java.util.SortedSet<java.lang.String> functions,
                       java.lang.String functionName,
                       Callable functionCall,
                       java.lang.String[] functionArgs)
                throws java.lang.AssertionError
        Adds the given function to both the given Map and the given SortedSet. This method is intended to make the use of TestProgram.defaultHelp easier by performing the appropriate Map.put call, and creating the elements of the sorted set in the form
        functionName(functonArg0, functonArg1, functonArg2, …)
        in a single call.

        The method requires functionCall.argNum and functionArgs.length to match if functionCall.argNum is not -1. Do not use this method if you require them to differ for any reason.

        This method does not check for any sort of correspondence between the existing elements of map and functions

        Parameters:
        map - The map, as required by TestProgram(Map)
        functions - The set of functions, as required by TestProgram.defaultHelp
        functionName - The name of the function to be added
        functionCall - The Callable that performs the call of the function to be added
        functionArgs - The list of arguments of the function to be added
        Throws:
        java.lang.AssertionError - if, when functionCall.argNum() == -1, it turns out that functionCall.argNum() != functionArgs.length

      • buildFunction

        private static java.lang.String buildFunction(java.lang.String functionName,
                                              java.lang.String[] functionArgs)
        Turns the function name and argument names given into a single string of the form
        functionName(functonArg<sub>0</sub>, functonArg<sub>1</sub>, functonArg<sub>2</sub>, &hellip;)
        Parameters:
        functionName - the name of the function
        functionArgs - the names of the arguments of the function

      • put

        public static void put(java.util.Map<java.lang.String,Callable> map,
                       java.lang.String functionName,
                       Callable functionCall,
                       java.lang.String[] functionArgs)
                throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException,
                       java.lang.ClassCastException,
                       java.lang.AssertionError
        Adds the given function to the given map and to the given map's “help” function, provided it is a TestProgram.defaultHelp instance. If the map does not map "help" to a defaultHelp instance, the function should be added, and the help function replaced, using Map.put,

        The method requires functionCall.argNum and functionArgs.length to match if functionCall.argNum is not -1. Do not use this method if you require them to differ for any reason.

        This method assumes the help function contained by the map is a correct TestProgram.defaultHelp instance. This means it assumes that another function by the given name doesn't already exist. If one does exist, but the arguments are different, the "help" function will print both, the previously existing version, and the new version. This is done so mainly for efficiency, and because the existing version is assumed to be valid (say, belonging to a superclass). If classes require the existing version not to be printed, they must remove it themselves.

        Parameters:
        map - The map, as required by TestProgram(Map)
        functionName - The name of the function to be added
        functionCall - The Callable that performs the call of the function to be added
        functionArgs - The list of arguments of the function to be added
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If the given map does not contain a "help" function
        java.lang.ClassCastException - If the map does contain a "help" function, but it is not a defaultHelp instance
        java.lang.AssertionError - if, when functionCall.argNum() == -1, it turns out that functionCall.argNum() != functionArgs.length
